content.description: A preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear slight to others. Individuals perform repetitive behaviors or mental acts in response to these concerns, causing significant distress or impairment.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects/flaws in appearance not observable or slight to others. B. At some point, performance of repetitive behaviors (mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (comparing appearance to others) in response. C. Clinically significant distress or impairment. D. Appearance preoccupation not better explained by concerns with body fat/weight in an eating disorder.
content.prevalence: Approximately 2% in the general population; higher rates in dermatology, cosmetic surgery, and orthodontic settings.
content.age_of_onset: Typically emerges in adolescence, coinciding with increased self-consciousness about appearance.
content.prognosis: Often chronic without treatment. Early intervention with psychotherapy and/or medication improves outcomes.

circuitry: Hyperactivity in the frontostriatal and occipitotemporal networks, especially the left hemisphere visual processing regions, leading to detail-focused processing.
Abnormalities in amygdala and anterior cingulate activation linked to heightened emotional salience of perceived defects.
neurochemistry: Possible dysregulation in serotonin pathways, similar to OCD; some evidence for dopaminergic involvement.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Family history of OCD or anxiety disorders; early teasing, abuse, or cultural pressures regarding appearance increase vulnerability.

history_psychosocial: Onset and course of appearance concerns; specific body areas involved.
Time spent daily on preoccupation and related behaviors.
History of cosmetic procedures and satisfaction with results.
Suicidality, self-harm history, comorbid psychiatric conditions.
medical_assessment: Physical exam to rule out true anomalies.
Dermatologic or dental evaluation only when clinically indicated.
Avoid unnecessary cosmetic referrals without psychiatric screening.
standardized_measures: BDD-YBOCS (Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale modified for BDD).
risk_stratification: Assess for suicidal ideation or attempts (high rates in BDD).
Evaluate for social isolation, severe depression, or aggression toward perceived defect.
Identify history of poor outcomes from cosmetic procedures.
differential_diagnosis: OCD with contamination or symmetry themes.
evaluation.team_and_process: Coordinate with psychiatry, psychology, and primary care; educate non-psychiatric providers on risks of cosmetic intervention in untreated BDD.

core: Repetitive behaviors or mental acts in response
Distress or impairment related to appearance concerns
associated_features: Seeking reassurance or comparing with others

severity_levels.mild: Preoccupation present but manageable; repetitive behaviors under 1 hour/day.
severity_levels.severe: Preoccupation over 3–8 hours/day; severe avoidance and inability to function.

biological: Family history of OCD, BDD, or anxiety
Neurobiological abnormalities in visual and emotional processing circuits
environmental: Occupations or activities focused on looks

impact_on_life.school_work: Absenteeism, lateness due to grooming rituals; decreased performance.
impact_on_life.social: Avoidance of events; strained relationships; isolation.
impact_on_life.medical: Multiple unnecessary cosmetic procedures with poor satisfaction.
impact_on_life.emotional: High anxiety, depression, shame; increased suicide risk.

psychotherapy: CBT tailored for BDD with exposure and response prevention.
medications: SSRIs (fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, sertraline, escitalopram) at higher OCD-range doses.
Augmentation with atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) if delusional intensity persists.
lifestyle_interventions: Reduce mirror-checking and avoidance through graded exposure.
care_coordination: Educate dermatologists/plastic surgeons to screen for BDD.
Collaborate with family/support network for adherence and monitoring.

treatment_goals: Prevent relapse and reduce suicide risk.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing distress solely to low self-esteem or depression without assessing appearance preoccupation.
Misinterpreting as vanity or normal adolescent concern.
Overlooking in males, where BDD may focus on muscle size (muscle dysmorphia).
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling normal appearance dissatisfaction as BDD without significant distress or impairment.
Confusing with culturally normative grooming or fitness focus.
Misdiagnosing eating disorders as BDD when weight/shape is the primary concern.

insight: Good/fair insight: recognizes beliefs are probably not true
Poor insight: thinks beliefs are probably true
Absent insight/delusional beliefs: completely convinced beliefs are true
specifiers.muscle_dysmorphia: Preoccupation with idea that body build is too small or insufficiently muscular

self_help_strategies: Limit mirror use to functional purposes only.
Engage in activities unrelated to looks.

childhood: May present as reluctance to be photographed or avoidance of certain activities; excessive concern with a minor feature.
adolescence: Increased self-consciousness; long grooming times; school avoidance; possible onset of muscle dysmorphia in males.
adulthood: Occupational and relationship difficulties; chronic dissatisfaction despite procedures.

real_life_examples: A 16-year-old refuses to attend school because they believe their nose is 'deformed,' spending hours each morning applying makeup to cover it.
A 28-year-old bodybuilder spends 5 hours/day in the gym and avoids dating, convinced they are too small despite above-average muscle mass.
A 34-year-old undergoes multiple cosmetic surgeries but continues to feel 'ugly' and socially withdraws.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek professional help if preoccupation with appearance consumes more than an hour/day, causes distress or impairment, or if suicidal thoughts emerge.

challenging_factors: High comorbidity with depression or OCD
